Pure Logic
Logic helps us make sense of the world. We use it to build
bridges, send rockets to space, and create the phone or computer
you read this on right now. Logic gives us amazing power to solve
problems. But there's something important you should know:
logic alone can't answer all our questions or meet all our needs. It
has limits that affect us in big ways.
Think about the last time you felt moved by a beautiful sunset
or felt love for someone in your life. Logic can explain why the
sky turns orange and pink as the sun goes down. It can tell us
about chemicals in our brains when we feel love. But those
explan ations don't capture the full experience. They don't tell us
why beauty matters or why love feels meaningful. These gaps
show us where pure logic falls short.
Many people today believe that if something can't be proven
with logic or measured in a lab, it must not be real or important.
This view leaves many feeling empty inside.

When Rationalism Falls Short
Rationalism is the belief that reason and logic are the best or
only ways to find truth. This view became very popular during a
time called the Enlightenment when thinkers tried to move away
from superstition and blind faith. They wanted to build
knowledge  on solid ground. This move brought many good
things. It helped create modern science, medicine, and
technology. It helped us question harmful traditions and find
better ways to live.
But something unexpected happened as rationalism grew
stronger. People began to feel that life had less meaning. The
French philosopher Blaise Pascal saw this problem hundreds of
years ago. He wrote that reason alone makes people feel small
and lost in an empty universe. He said, "The heart has reasons that
reason cannot know." He didn't mean we should ignore logic. He
meant that human understanding needs both clear thinking and
deep feeling.
Today, many people experience what philosophers call "the
crisis of meaning.

an inner experience at all. Why does it feel like something to be
you? Why aren't you just a complex robot going through the
motions without any inner life? This is what philosophers call
"the hard problem of consciousness," and scientific materialism
has no answer for it.

rational? This might sound strange if you've been taught that faith

Antonio Damasio describes a case involving a man named Elliot
in his groundbreaking book Descartes’ Error: Emotion, Reason,
and the Human Brain  (1994). Elliot was a successful, intelligent
man who suffered damage to a part of his prefrontal cortex
(specifically the ventromedial prefrontal cortex) after surgery to
remove a brain tumor. Although his IQ and basic reasoning skills
remained intact, Elliot lost the ability to feel emotional responses
to decisions.

faced with even simple everyday choices — like selecting a time
for an appointment, picking a restaurant, or yes, choosing
between products in a supermarket. Because he couldn't "feel" the
emotional w eight of the options, every decision became an
endless analysis with no conclusion.
Damasio’s big insight was that emotion is essential to
rationality. Without emotional markers — what he later called
"somatic markers" — the brain can't properly prioritize or value
one option over another. Pure logic, without feeling, leads to
endless loo ps of meaningless comparisons.  In other words,
Elliot's experience is living proof of one of the central messages
of The Unified Mind : faith and reason, feeling and thinking, must
work together to create intelligent, grounded, human decisions.

chapter: Introduction
text:
The human  intellect  has been  our powerful  beacon  in our
quest  to comprehend  the universe,  yet there  are places  where
our intellectual  light  fails  to penetrate.  In the sprawling  cosmos
of understanding,  some  phenomena  resist  our traditional
explanations,  creating  dissonance  within  our scientific
discourse.  They  are like faint  signals  lost in the noise,
whispering  hints  of greater  realities  beyond  our conventional
frameworks.  This  book , "Signals  in the Noise:  Encountering  the
Limits  of Materialist  Science:  An Exploration  of Consciousness
and Reality,"  seeks  to tune  into and examine  these  elusive
signals.
What  are these  signals  that challenge  the status  quo of our
understanding?  Many  are classified  as Psi phenomena ,2 some  of
which  we will discuss  in detail.  But the real emphasis  will be one
class  called  near -death  experiences  (NDEs),  the mysterious
phenomena  that occur  at the fringes  of life and death.

Realism asserts that the external world exists independently
of our experience or interpretation. In other words, a tree falling

On the flip side, posits that reality is fundamentally a
construct of the mind. Essentially, the universe exists as we
perceive it; it's our consciousness that shapes our reality. From
this perspective, consciousness isn't just a byproduct of the
brain; it 's the cornerstone of existence.

This  claim  means  Western  civilization  is home  to a
transparent  set of pervasive  ontological  and epistemological
presuppositions.  Or another  way to say this is we believe  the
universe  is made  up of materials , and we are separate  and
distinct  objects  in it. In addition,  this worldview  claims  the only
valid  knowledge  is found  in “facts  and figures,”  the evidential
data  that can be observed  and measured  in concrete  terms.
Consequently,  we live in a world  defined  by an intermixture  of
Newtonian/Einsteinian  Materialism  and Judeo -Christian
theology.

experience  consciousness  events  that cannot  be explained  by
materialist  science.
Individually  they  are called  subjective  experiences.  Together
the study  of these  events  can be classified  as phenomenology.  In
this book , phenomenology  is primarily  concerned  with
systematically  reflecting  on and studying  the structures  of
consciousness  and the phenomena  that appear  in acts of
consciousness.  Phenomenology  can be differentiated  from  the
Cartesian  analysis  method,  which  sees  the world  as objects,  sets
of objects,  and objects  acting  and reacting  upon  one another.76
“The  phenomena  that appear  in acts of consciousness”
appear  to be objects  only  in our sensory  systems’
representations.  They  are then  further  distinguished  as isolates
or separate  elements  of physical  reality  because  of our language.
The universe  is whole  and complete,  as if of one holistic  weave .

Moving onto other theories of consciousness:
Dualism  suggests mind and matter are different yet
interactive, but it faces the interaction problem.
Materialism  posits consciousness as physical but struggles
to explain subjective experiences, known as 'qualia'.
Panpsychism  views consciousness as a universal feature
but leaves unanswered questions.
Emergentism  claims consciousness arises from complex
neural activities but hasn't fully explained how.
Quantum  theories speculate a role for quantum mechanics
but lack empirical evidence.
The real constant in this maze of ideas is human -made
confusion. Yes, we're conscious and material beings in what
appears to be an immaterial origin (the "implicative"). Is it
miraculous? No, it's likely the result of natural processes over an
unimaginable  timespan.

With  the discovery  of the quantum  level,  we know  this model  is

quantum  laws  at the subatomic  level  that we cannot  directly
experience  with  ordinary  biological  sensory  systems.

into a unified  whole.

This level is what I propose as best explained by idealism .
Bohm  used  the analogy  of a hologram  to explain  the
relationship  between  the implicate  and explicate  orders.  In a
hologram,  the entire  image  is enfolded  in every  part  of the
holographic  plate.  When  the plate  is illuminated,  the image  is
unfolded  and appears  to be projected  into space.  Similarly,  in
the implicate  order,  the entire  universe  is enfolded  in each  part,
and the explicate  order  is the unfolded  holographic  projection
of this enfoldment.96
According  to Bohm,  the explicate  order  emerges  from  and
returns  to the implicate  order.  The implicate  order  provides  the
underlying  source  of information  and energy  for manifesting  the
explicate  order.  The explicate  order,  in turn,  feeds  back  into the
implicate  order  and influences  its enfoldment.

The philosophy of science delves deep into understanding the
foundational principles of the scientific method. At its core, it
seeks to distinguish what makes something truly scientific as
opposed to non -scientific. This exploration extends to the
ethical considerations intrinsic to scientific endeavors.
Underpinning the scientific method are several pivotal
assumptions stemming from philosophy. These include the
belief that reality is both objective and unchanging. It also
presumes that humans have the cap acity to accurately grasp and
perceive this reality. Moreover, there's a steadfast conviction
that for every facet of the real world, there's a logical and
rational explanation waiting to be uncovered.
Methodological naturalism posits that the natural world, as
we observe it, is the only reality and is the sole focus of scientific
inquiry. These assumptions serve as a foundation upon which
the edifice of science stands.

For instance, logical positivists emphasize the verifiability
principle, suggesting that meaningful statements are only those
that can be empirically verified. Empiricists, on the other hand,
champion the idea that knowledge is derived primarily from
senso ry experience. Falsificationism, proposed by Karl Popper,
argues that scientific theories can never be proven, but they can
be falsified or disproven.
However, it's worth noting that each of these perspectives,
while contributing valuable insights, has also faced its fair share
of criticisms.

As I delved  even  deeper  into my exploration  of consciousness,

interpretations  no longer  explained  the actual  territory  the map
was inten ded to represent . In this chapter,  my direction  shifts

evidence.  They  challenge  time -honored  materialist  theories  and
establish  an interesting  dialogue  with  post -materialist
viewpoints.  These  instances,  straddling  the thin  line between
life and death,  hold  the potential  to shine  a light  on the deep  and
occasionally  contradictory  intricacies  of consciousness.

A non -dualistic explanation of the cosmos is rooted in the
belief that there isn't a fundamental distinction or duality
between various aspects of the universe, such as mind and

seen as inter connected, interdependent, and originating from a
singular source or reality.

in relation to the cosmos:
Unified Reality:  At the core of non -dualism is the idea that
everything in the universe emerges from a single, undivided
reality. This means that the distinctions we see —like between
ourselves and the external world —are mere perceptions and not
ultimate truths.
Interconnectedness:  Everything in the cosmos is deeply
interconnected.

puzzle,  and challenge  us. After  our in-depth  discussion  in the
previous  chapter  regarding  whether  the brain  is solely
responsible  for consciousness,  I now  pivot  our inquiry  to a
question  that has captivated  philosophers,  scientists,  and
Western  thinkers  for centuries:  Where  is consciousness?
As I delve  into this chapter,  I will continue  to utilize  the
scientific  method  as our guide,  venturing  further  into the realms
of quantum  theory  and cognitive  neuroscience.  Through  the
lens of these  pivotal  scientific  fields,  I am granted  a profound
perspective  on consciousness  and its potential  location.

Monism and non -dualism are philosophical tenets that
frequently overlap in discussions but hold distinct meanings.
Monism posits that reality is founded upon a singular substance
or essence. This philosophy can manifest as materialistic, where
reality is b ased on physical substance, or idealistic, where the
mental essence takes precedence.
On the other hand, non -dualism suggests that reality
surpasses simplistic binary concepts like 'one' and 'many.' It
advocates for an interconnectedness where delineations
between subject and object, self and other, or even appearance
and reality dissolve.
One interpretation suggests that monism is akin to a
scientific revelation, asserting that all existence shares a
unifying essence. Conversely, non -dualism represents the
practice of perceiving life without compartmentalization. While
monism might present an objective truth about reality, non -
dualism delves into the subjective experience of this truth.

long captivated thinkers from philosophy to cognitive science.
The definitive verdict? We’re still figuring it out. But let's walk
through some dominant perspectives.
At its core, consciousness is our intimate window into the
world — our thoughts, emotions, and experiences. Free will, on
the other hand, is often seen as our ability to make choices,
seemingly untouched by external influences.
A prevalent perspective insists that consciousness and free
will are inseparable partners. To them, our conscious
experiences are the bedrock of our choices, and without
consciousness, the very concept of free will crumbles.
Yet, there are dissenting voices.

chapter: The interplay of language and our reality.
text:
Language not only reflects our perception of reality but also
plays a role in shaping it, largely because our linguistic
structures have evolved based on our ecological needs. For
instance, certain indigenous groups in the Amazon have
languages that don't differentiate between the myriad colors of
the jungle. To them, the jungle appears as a cohesive tapestry of
color. Their linguistic framework also limits numerical
distinctions to concepts akin to "one, two, and many."
A frequently cited, albeit somewhat oversimplified, example
is the claim that Arctic peoples have numerous words for snow.
The idea is that their survival in harsh snowy environments
necessitated a more nuanced understanding and description of
snow. While the exact number of words and the nuances behind
them can be debated, the underlying principle remains: our
language evolves in tandem with our ecological needs.

chapter: Pre and  post -death  phenomena .
text:
According  to studies  by Peter  Fenwick ,212 several  phases  can
be experienced  by people  who  are in the process  of dying.  His
research  is based  on reports  of people  who  are at the bedside  of
the dying.  The first  phase  might  be a premonition  that
sometimes  happens  some  days  before  dying.  As we saw in the
case  of Abraham  Lincoln,  he experienced  a premonition  in his
dream.  The second  phase  consists  of deathbed  visions  of people,
spirits,  or pets  who  will come  to help  the dying  person.
Sometimes  they  leave  but say they’ll  come  back.  Sometimes  they
stay until  the end.  Then  shortly  before  death,  a dying  person
may  seem  to be in and out of another  realm  of reality.  In some
instances,  like in the cases  of Steve  Jobs  and Thomas  Edison,
they  report  their  impressions  as though  they  are seeing  another
reality.  Occasionally  another  after -death  event  happens.

Here  are simplified  definitions  of the Buddhist  concepts  of
gross,  subtle,  and very  subtle  bodies:
The gross  body is the physical  form  we can see and touch,
made  of flesh,  bones,  blood,  and other  material  elements.  It is
the basis  for the gross  mind,  which  depends  on the body  and
ceases  when  the body  dies.  The gross  body  is subject  to aging,
sickness,  and death.  It is also influenced  by karma  and
afflictions.
The subtle  body  is the energetic  system  that supports  the
subtle  mind,  which  underpins  the five senses  and provides
information  to the very  subtle  mind.  The subtle  body  consists  of
channels,  winds,  and drops  circulating  throughout  the body  and
carrying  the subtle  consciousness.  The subtle  body  can be
purified  and transformed  through  meditation  practices  such  as
yoga,  tantra,  and deity  visualization.

History  of Death
Until  the last few decades,  a simple  definition  of death  has
been  sufficient  in the West.  For instance,  most  people  don’t
know  that in the “olden  days,”  when  an English  sailor  was sewn

through  his nose.  That  was the British  Navy’s  way of being  sure
he was dead.  Fortunately,  that practice  is now  obsolete.
Since  the development  of modern  medical  techniques,  we can
bring  people  back  from  death  as we understood  it–clinical
death —as previously  defined.  The moment  of irreversible  death
is not as straightforward  as we once  thought.

chapter: What  about  DNA?
text:
Isn’t  what  Sheldrake  claims  the work  of DNA?  Most  of us
assume  that DNA  produces  who  we are, but DNA  is the
information  necessary  for making  our bodies.  Its main  purpose
is to direct  the construction  of our bodies.  It is the blueprint  or
code  for the construction  of all living  beings  but only  provides
instruction  on creating  the building  blocks,  the amino  acids,  and
proteins.  216 It seems  to me that both  Barron  and Sheldrake
come  to a similar  conclusion  that other  factors  are at work  to
determine  the overall  patterns  of how  to put those  proteins  or
building  blocks  together.
For instance,  if we think  of a cell as a brick  in the construction
of our bodies,  knowing  how  to construct  a brick  is not enough  to
explain  how  to build  a brick  building.  Most  recently , research  at
Tufts  University  has shown  promising  results  in this regard.

As I wrote  before,  the Zero  Point  Field  is the most  basic  level
of the universe.  It contains  Zero -point  Energy  299 (ZPE) , the
lowest  possible  energy  a quantum  system  may  have.  Unlike
classical  physics,  quantum  systems  constantly  fluctuate  in their
lowest  energy  state.  According  to quantum  field  theory,  the
universe  is not made  up of isolated  particles  but continuously
fluctuating  quantum  fields  of potential  particles . In quantum
field  theory,  zero -point  energy  is the lowest  possible  energy  that
a quantum  system  may  have.  It is the energy  of the system's
ground  state , even  at absolute  zero  temperature.  This  energy
arises  from  the inherent  uncertainty  in the position  and
momentum  of a quantum  “particle ” (point of energy)  which
gives  rise to fluctuations  in the system's  energy  even  when  it is
in its lowest  energy  state.
In this sense,  quantum  fields  are made  up of zero -point
energy.

Manifesto  for a Post -Materialistic  Science
We are a group  of internationally  known  scientists,  from  a
variety  of scientific  fields  (biology,  neuroscience,  psychology,
medicine,  psychiatry),  who  participated  in an international
summit  on post -materialist  science,  spirituality  and society.  The
summit  was co-organized  by Gary  E. Schwartz,  PhD  and Mario
Beauregard,  PhD , the University  of Arizona,  and Lisa  Miller,
PhD , Columbia  University.  This  summit  was held  at Canyon
Ranch  in Tucson,  Arizona,  on February  7-9, 2014.  Our purpose
was to discuss  the impact  of the materialist  ideology  on science
and the emergence  of a post -materialist  paradigm  for science,
spirituali ty, and society.  We have  come  to the following
conclusions:

chapter: The modern  scientific  worldview  is predominantly
text:
predicated  on assumptions  that are closely  associated  with
classical  physics.  Materialism —the idea  that matter  is the only
reality —is one of these  assumptions.  A related  assumption  is
reductionism , the notion  that complex  things  can be understood
by reducing  them  to the interactions  of their  parts,  or to simpler
or more  fundamental  things  such  as tiny material  particles.

chapter: During  the 19th  century,  these  assumptions  narrowed,
text:
turned  into dogmas,  and coalesced  into an ideological  belief
system  that came  to be known  as "scientific  materialism."  This
belief  system  implies  that the mind  is nothing  but the physical
activity  of the brain,  and that our thoughts  cannot  have  any
effect  upon  our brains  and bodies,  our actions,  and the physical
world.

chapter: The ideology  of scientific  materialism  became  dominant  in
text:
academia  during  the 20th  century.  So dominant  that a majority
of scientists  started  to believe  that it was based  on established
Signals in the Noise

chapter: Scientific  methods  based  upon  materialistic  philosophy  have
text:
been  highly  successful  in not only  increasing  our understanding
of nature  but also in bringing  greater  control  and freedom
through  advances  in technology.

chapter: However,  the nearly  absolute  dominance  of materialism  in
text:
the academic  world  has seriously  constricted  the sciences  and
hampered  the development  of the scientific  study  of mind  and
spirituality.  Faith  in this ideology,  as an exclusive  explanatory
framework  for reality,  has compelled  scientists  to neglect  the
subjective  dimension  of human  experience.  This  has led to a
severely  distorted  and impoverished  understanding  of ourselves
and our place  in nature.

chapter: Science  is first  and foremost  a non-dogmatic,  open -minded
text:
method  of acquiring  knowledge  about  nature  through  the
observation,  experimental  investigation,  and theoretical
explanation  of phenomena.  Its methodology  is not synonymous
with  materialism  and should  not be committed  to any particular
beliefs,  dogmas,  or ideologies.

chapter: At the end of the nineteenth  century,  physicists  discovered
text:
empirical  phenomena  that could  not be explained  by classical
physics.  This  led to the development,  during  the 1920s  and early

text:
theory  (QT). QT has questioned  the material  foundations  of the
world  by showing  that atoms  and subatomic  particles  are not
solid  objects —they  do not exist  with  certainty  at definite  spatial
locations  and definite  times.  Most  importantly,  QT explicitly
introduced  the mind  into its basic  conceptual  structure  since  it
was found  that particles  being  observed  and the observer —the
physicist  and the method  used  for observation —are linked.
According  to one interpretation  of QT, this phenomenon  implies
that the consciousness  of the observer  is vital  to the existence  of
the physical  events  being  observed,  and that mental  events  can
affect  the physical  world.  The results  of recent  experiments
support  this interpretation.  These  results  suggest  that the

text:
reality,  and that it cannot  be fully  understood  without  making
reference  to the mind.

chapter: Psychological  studies  have  shown  that conscious  mental
text:
activity  can causally  influence  behavior,  and that the
explanatory  and predictive  value  of agentic  factors  (e.g., beliefs,
goals,  desires  and expectations)  is very  high.  Moreover,  research
in psychoneuroimmunology  indicates  that our thoughts  and
emotions  can markedly  affect  the activity  of the physiological
systems  (e.g.,  immune,  endocrine,  cardiovascular)  connected  to
the brain.  In other  respects,  neuroimaging  studies  of emotional
self-regulation,  psychotherapy,  and the placebo  effect
demonstrate  that mental  events  significantly  influence  the
activity  of the brain.

chapter: Studies  of the so-called  "psi phenomena"  indicate  that we
text:
can sometimes  receive  meaningful  information  without  the use
of ordinary  senses,  and in ways  that transcend  the habitual
space  and time  constraints.  Furthermore,  psi research
demonstrates  that we can mentally  influence —at a distance —
physical  devices  and living  organisms  (including  other  human
beings).  Psi research  also shows  that distant  minds  may  behave
in ways  that are nonlocally  correlated,  i.e. the correlations
between  distant  minds  are hypothesized  to be unmediated  (they
are not linked  to any known  energetic  signal),  unmitigated  (they
do not degrade  with  increasing  distance),  and immediate  (they
appear  to be simultaneous).  These  events  are so common  that
they  cannot  be viewed  as anomalous  nor as exceptions  to
natural  laws,  but as indications  of the need  for a broader

One  of the earliest  and most  persistent  of the physiological
theories  proposed  for NDEs  is that lowered  levels  of oxygen
(hypoxia  or anoxia),  perhaps  accompanied  by increased  levels
of carbon  dioxide  (hypercarbia),  have  produced  hallucinations
(Blackmore,  1993;  Lampert,  1994;  Rodin,  1980).  Although  such
changes  are potentially  a factor,  particularly  among  NDEs
occurring  in connection  with  cardiac  impairment  or arrest,
NDEs  also occur  in many  circumstances  in which  changes  in
oxygen  or carbon  dioxide  levels  are unlikely,  such  as non - life -
threatening  illnesses,  falls,  or other  near  - accidents.
Furthermore,  despite  claims  to the contrary,  the experiential
phenomena  associated  with  such  changes  are only  superficially
similar  to NDEs.

Problems  with  models  based  on the release  of endorphins  or
similar  substances  soon  became  apparent,  however.  Most  such
neurochemicals  produce  long  - lasting  effects  once  they  are
released;  the injection  of endorphins  in pain  patients,  for
example,  produces  relief  from  pain  lasting  for hours  (Oyama  et
al., 1980).  In contrast,  the onset  and cessation  of the NDE  and
its associated  features  are usually  quite  abrupt,  with  the pain
relief  lasting  only  as long  as the NDE  itself,  which  may  be only
seconds.
Furthermore,  although  the release  of substances  such  as
endorphins  might  account  for the cessation  of pain  and the
feelings  of joy and peace,  it fails  to account  for many  other
important  components  of NDEs,  such  as the out - of - body
experience,  seeing  deceased  persons,  a life review,  and the
transformative  effects.

Neuroanatomical  Models
The need  for a more  comprehensive  and searching
comparison  between  the phenomenology  of NDEs  and that
associated  with  various  purported  mechanisms  for them
becomes  even  more  apparent  when  we examine  another  major
component  of most  current  physiological  theories  of NDEs.
Behind  most  of these  theories  is an assumption  that
abnormal  activity  of the limbic  system  or the temporal  lobes,
whether  produced  by anoxia,  endorphins,  ketamine,  or some
other  mechanism,  produces  NDE  - like experiences.  M. Morse
et al. (1989),  for example,  proposed  a model  in which
imbalances  in serotonin  or other  monoamines  lead  to abnormal
activity  in the temporal  lobes.

First, electrical  stimulation  of cortex  is massive  and grossly
unlike  ordinary  physiological  stimulation.  It does  not, and
cannot,  result  simply  in a localized  “activation”  of the stimulated
region.  Indeed,  as Penfield  (1975)  himself  clearly  recognized,  its
predominant  effects  are disruption  of electrical  activity  in the
immediate  vicinity  of the electrode,  accompanied  by abnormal
patterns  of discharge  into additional  cortical  or subcortical
areas  to which  the stimulated  cortex  itself  is linked  by both
forward  and backward  projections.  These  remote  influences,
moreover,  may  be either  excitatory  or inhibitory  in character.

therefore  that they  may  also survive  the more  permanent

Several  features  of NDEs,  however,  call into question
whether  current  psychological  or physiological  theories  of NDEs

Enhanced  Mentation
As we mentioned  earlier,  perhaps  the most  important  of
these  features,  because  it is so commonly  reported  in NDEs,  is
the occurrence  of full - fledged  mentation,  either  normal  or even
enhanced  mental  activity,  at times  when,  according  to
conventional  psychophysiological  theory,  such  activity  should
be diminishing,  or even  not possible.  Individuals  reporting
NDEs  often  describe  the experience  as being  altogether  unlike  a
dream,  in that their  mental  processes  during  the NDE  were
remarkably  clear  and lucid  and their  sensory  experiences
unusually  vivid,  equaling  or even  surpassing  those  of their
normal  waking  state.

Cardiac  arrest,  however,  is a physiologically  brutal  event.
Cerebral  functioning  shuts  down  within  a few seconds.  Whether
the heart  actually  stops  beating  entirely  or goes  into ventricular
fibrillation,  the result  is essentially  instantaneous  circulatory
arrest,  with  blood  flow  and oxygen  uptake  in the brain  plunging
swiftly  to near  - zero  levels.  EEG  signs  of cerebral  ischemia,
typically  with  global  slowing  and loss of fast activity,  are visually
detectable  within  6 – 10 seconds,  and progress  to isoelectricity
(flat  - line EEGs)  within  10 – 20 seconds  of the onset  of arrest.
In sum,  full arrest  leads  rapidly  to establishment  of three
major  clinical  signs  of death  — absence  of cardiac  output,
absence  of respiration,  and absence  of brainstem  reflexes  — and
provides  the best  model  we have  of the dying  process  (DeVries,

chapter: Appendix  D:
text:
Survival  of Consciousness  After  Death
On July  6, 2022,  this essay  appeared  on the IONS  (Institute
of Noetic  Sciences)  website  noetic.org/blog.  It was written  by
the Science  Team  (https://noetic.org/science/scientists -
fellows/)  at IONS  headed  by Dean  Radin.  Ph.D.325
What,  if anything,  survives  physical  death?  That  was  the
motivation  behind  this IONS  essay  aimed  to advance  the
understanding  of the complex  and fascinating  topic  of survival
of consciousness.
We can start  by considering  two extremes:
On the one hand,  we have  the idea  that  the material  world  is
fundamental,  and that  consciousness  is an emergent  property.
On the other  hand,  we have  the theory  that  consciousness  is
fundamental  and manifests  all that  we see around  us.
The first  perspective  dismisses  survival  of consciousness
after  death  as a possibility,  while  according  to the latter,
consciousness  is all there  is.

chapter: Appendix  D:
text:

The first  perspective  dismisses  survival  of consciousness
after  death  as a possibility,  while  according  to the latter,
consciousness  is all there  is. People’s  beliefs  are not black  or
white  but lie somewhere  in the middle.
We can explore  these  nuances  through  four  main  questions:
•What  survives?
•Why  improve  beliefs  in the survival  of consciousness
after  death?
•What  are the major  categories  of evidence  for
survival?
•What  experiments  can advance  our understanding
of survival?
These  questions  inspired  the creation  of this award -winning
essay,  written  by IONS  scientists  Dean  Radin,  Helané  Wahbeh,
and Arnaud  Delorme.
Signals in the Noise

chapter: What  survives?
text:
The researchers  established  five levels  of survival  of
consciousness  to help  evaluate  the evidence  categories  more
easily.  Consciousness  is defined  as awareness  and identity  – a
sense  of subjective  awareness  that  includes  one’s  surroundings
together  with  a sense  of self and personal  memories.
The five levels  were  defined  as follows:
•Level  0: Nothing  survives.  All aspects  of being
human  are dissolved  at the point  of bodily  death.  This  is
compatible  with  the materialistic  worldview  where  you
are basically  your  brain  – so when  the brain  dies,  it
could  mean  that  all aspects  of you do, too.
•Level  1: Pure  awareness  survives.  Personal  identity
and memories  vanish.  What  survives  can be seen  as a
formless,  transcendent  state,  with  no perception  of the
environment  being  different  than  itself.
•Level  2: Awareness  and limited  sense  of identity
survive.

•Level  3: Awareness  and identity  survive.  This

All levels  except  for level  0 include  some  level  of survival .
Since  level  1 is pure  awareness  without  identity,  the
researchers  chose  to focus  on levels  2-4 in the essay.

chapter: Why  improve  beliefs  in the survival  of consciousness
text:
after  death?
The question  remains  – why  dive  into this topic  in the first
place?  It may  seem  like an impossible  nut to crack,  with  little
relevance  beyond  stimulating  intellectual  and existential
curiosity.
This  is not the case.  Previous  studies  have  shown  that  people
who  believe  in some  form  of survival  experience  higher  well -
being.  Believing  in a life after  death  goes  hand  in hand  with
believing  in justice  for all, reduced  psychiatric  conditions,  and
a more  peaceful  life.
On the contrary,  not believing  in the afterlife  is associated
with  the materialistic  worldview,  where  objects  and things  are
all that  count,  and one’s  actions  lack  energetic  consequences.  It
can feed  nihilism  and qualities  like greed,  envy,  and selfishness.
It can also  worsen  depression.  What’s  the point  of doing
anything  if there’s  no meaning?

It can also  worsen  depression.  What’s  the point  of doing

The main  focus  from  a well -being  point  of view  could  be to
increase  beliefs  in the survival  of consciousness  rather  than
trying  to prove  survival  as “real.”
What  are the major  categories  of evidence  for
survival?
Here  are the categories  that  may  suggest  survival,
presented  in descending  order  of credibility:
Category  1: Mental  mediumship
Mental  mediumship  is undertaken  sometimes  as a seance
with  a medium  and a group  of sitters.  The sitters  are
traditionally  family  members,  friends,  and loved  ones  of the
deceased  person.  Sometimes  it happens  in one-on-one sessions.
Signals in the Noise

chapter: The medium  acts as a channel  for the deceased  person.
text:
They’re  literally  the medium  by which  the living  and the dead
can communicate  with  each  other.
Sometimes,  this happens  through  trance  channeling,  where
the medium  goes  into a trance,  and the non-physical  being
communicates  through  the medium’s  body  or voice.  Other
times,  the medium  “tunes  in” and shares  any messages  they
receive.
Most  of the time,  mediumship  implies  that  the medium
reaches  out to the deceased  person.  But mediumship  can also
occur  spontaneously  through  so-called  drop -in
communication.  Verifying  the information  received  makes  it
harder  for skeptics  to dismiss  mediumship  as invented
messages.
Criticism  against  mental  mediumship  is that  the
information  can be biased  by so-called  cold  reading.  This
means  that  the medium  picks  up on non-verbal  cues  like body
language  from  the sitter  and adjusts  their  message
accordingly.

Another  mental  mediumship  phenomenon  supporting

Category  2: Physical  mediumship
Physical  mediumship  differs  from  mental  mediumship  in
that  some  physical  substance  is manifested.  These  substances
or materials  are thought  to be associated  with  the deceased
person.
One common  way  is through  the production  of ectoplasm,  a
type  of energetic  material  used  by spirits  to communicate  with
humans  or interact  with  the physical  world.  Some  physical
mediums  have  allegedly  had psychokinetic  effects  on
photography  by creating  images  on undeveloped  film.  This  is
once  again  at the tricky  intersection  between  survival  and psi.

chapter: Category  3: Reincarnation
text:
Reincarnation  refers  to being  reborn  in another  body.  It is
central  in certain  cultures  and religions,  notably  Buddhism
and Hinduism.
One of the most  remarkable  sources  of evidence  is the studies
made  by psychiatrist  Ian Stevenson.  He studied  over  2,500
cases  of reincarnation  and wrote  12 books  on the topic.  There
are several  cases  of children  making  verifiable  claims  about
things  they  couldn’t  know  in any logical  way.  The most
unambiguous  ones  are those  where  the child  has gifts  and
talents  that  the deceased  possessed  or marks  and deformities
corresponding  to an injury  related  to the cause  of death  of the
supposedly  reincarnated  person.
The main  challenge  with  investigating  reincarnation  as
proof  for the survival  of consciousness  is that  only
retrospective  studies  are possible.

Category  4: NDEs
NDEs  (Near  Death  Experiences)  refer  to an altered  state  of
consciousness  following  a nearly  fatal  accident  or event.  It can
happen  after  resuscitation  and the physical  body  being
declared  dead.
People  who  have  experienced  an NDE  report  a feeling  of
“leaving  the body”  and seeing  everything  from  above.  This  is
generally  followed  by feelings  of peace,  joy, and ecstasy.  The
person  can even  experience  traveling  through  a tunnel  filled
with  bright  light.  Another  common  event  is to meet  and
communicate  with  passed  loved  ones.

chapter: NDEs  are often  described  as “hyper -real,”  more  real than
text:
reality.  People  experiencing  NDEs  often  report  positive  life
changes  that  are not present  in those  nearing  death  without
having  an NDE,  such  as loss of fear  of death,  increased  love
and compassion  for their  loved  ones,  and major  life changes
for the better.  Most  people  who  undergo  an NDE  have
increased  confidence  in the survival  of consciousness
afterward.  The experience  is often  described  as transformative
and can encourage  exploring  a spiritual  path.
Non -believers  may  motivate  the above  experiences  as mere
hallucinations  caused  by an oxygen -deprived  brain.  However,
the experiences  can differ  from  what  is known  about  that  kind
of hallucinations.
People’s  ability  to see and perceive  things  in the physical
world  during  an NDE  is a striking  argument  for its legitimacy
as an indicator  of consciousness  separate  from  the brain.

limited  to the brain!
Despite  these  fascinating  stories,  NDEs  have  little  validity
from  a strictly  scientific  perspective.  This  is because  the
evidence  is purely  anecdotal.

Why  people  are skeptical
There  are various  reasons  why  people  are skeptical  about
the survival  of consciousness.  The most  common  reasons  are
personal  beliefs,  atheism,  and strict  beliefs  in a materialistic
world.
As mentioned  at the beginning  of the article,  survival  doesn’t
make  sense  in a materialistic  worldview.  If consciousness  is
generated  by the brain,  there  would  logically  be nothing  left as
the brain  ceases  to function.
Successful  results  in the top three  experiments  described
above  would  be a step  toward  inviting  non-believers  to open
up to the idea  of survival  of consciousness.  This  is since  science
has arguably  the most  authority  in interpreting  reality  today.

chapter: It is appropriate to create a hypothesis to test a phenomenon that
text:
cannot be falsified by current scientific evidence. The scientific
method involves formulating hypotheses, conducting experiments or
gathering data to test those hypotheses, and then analy zing the
results. If there is a phenomenon that lacks sufficient evidence to
confirm or refute its existence, proposing a hypothesis and designing
experiments to test it can be a valid approach.
Scientific progress often involves exploring unexplained phenomena
or challenging existing theories. By formulating a hypothesis and
conducting rigorous experiments, scientists can gather empirical
evidence to either support or refute the hypothesis. This process
allows for the advancement of scientific knowledge and the
refinement of theories.
It's important to note that the inability to falsify a phenomenon with
current evidence does not mean that the phenomenon is
automatically accepted as true or valid.

chapter: Navigating the labyrinthine corridors of philosophical discourse can
text:
sometimes feel as if we're deciphering a foreign language. One such
term that emerges from these hallways is "ontological primitive."
Now, what on Earth does that mean, right? Let's break  it down
together in a manner that's both approachable and intellectually
stimulating.
At its core, the term "ontology" concerns itself with the nature
of existence. What does it mean for something to "be" or to "exist"?
Philosophers love pondering this question on rainy afternoons (and
sunny ones too, for that matter). An "ontological primi tive" is
essentially a foundational or basic concept that we don't further define
in terms of other concepts. It's like a building block of reality or
thought that we just accept as a given, without needing to dissect it
further.
Imagine a set of those colorful building blocks children play
with. Some might represent concepts we're familiar with in daily life,
such as "love", "time", or "energy .

further.
Imagine a set of those colorful building blocks children play
with. Some might represent concepts we're familiar with in daily life,
such as "love", "time", or "energy ." An ontological primitive would be
like the most basic block that we can't split any further. It's a starting
point. From this, we construct more complex ideas and realities.
Diving a bit into your sphere of interest, the concept of
"consciousness" has often been treated as an ontological primitive by
some thinkers. That is, consciousness is so fundamental to our
understanding of the self and reality that it becomes challenging , if
not impossible, to define it in terms of something more basic.
Thinking about such foundational ideas can be a wonderful
exercise in mindfulness. It nudges us to step back from our automatic,
day-to-day understanding of the world and dive deeper into the
building blocks of reality and thought.

Bohm's Implicate and Explicate Order:
In Bohm's view, the implicate (or enfolded) order is the

chapter: The Copenhagen interpretation is a collection of views about the
text:
meaning of quantum theory principally attributed to Niels Bohr and
Werner Heisenberg. It is one of the oldest of numerous proposed
interpretations of quantum theory, as features of it date t o the
development of quantum theory during 1925 –1927, and it remains
one of the most commonly taught. There is no definitive historical
statement of what the Copenhagen interpretation is. There are some
fundamental agreements and disagreements between the views of
Bohr and Heisenberg. For example, Heisenberg emphasized a sharp
"cut" between the observer (or the instrument) and the system being
observed, while Bohr offered an interpretation that is independent of
a subjective observer or measurement or collapse, which relies on an
"irreversible" or effectively irreversible process, which could take
place within the quantum system.

chapter: Emergent property and emergent phenomenon are closely related
text:
concepts, but there are some subtle differences between them.
An emergent phenomenon refers to a complex behavior or pattern
that arises from the interactions of individual components in a
system, without being directly programmed or designed into the
system. For example, flocking behavior of birds, traffic jams, and  ant
colonies are all examples of emergent phenomena.
An emergent property, on the other hand, refers to a characteristic or
behavior of a system that is not present in any of its individual
components but arises as a result of their interactions. In other words,
it is a property that emerges at the system le vel, rather than at the
component level. For example, consciousness is often considered an
emergent property of the brain, as it cannot be explained by the
behavior of individual neurons but arises from the complex
interactions between them.

chapter: René Descartes (1596 –1650) was indeed a dualist, specifically a
text:
cal and logical arguments rather than religious doctrine.
He arrived at his dualist position through a method of skeptical
inquiry, which is encapsulated in his famous Meditations on First
Philosophy. He first questioned all of his previous beliefs and then
tried to establish a firm foundation of knowledge based on the
indubitable fact of his own existence, summed up in his famous
dictum "Cogito, ergo sum" ("I think, therefore I am"). Based on this,
he posited that the thinking mind must be distinct from the physical
body.
However, this is not to say that his arguments were not met with
controversy. Many critics argue that Descartes' dualism leads to what
is known as the "mind -body problem," the question of how the mental
and physical can causally interact if they are distin ct and separate
substances.

chapter: Consciousness and awareness are two concepts that are closely
text:
related, and they are often used interchangeably in everyday
language. However, within the fields of cognitive science, philosophy,
and psychology, they can have somewhat different nuances and
connotations.
Consciousness is the state of being awake and aware of one's
surroundings. It's a term used to describe our subjective experience,
the so -called "phenomenal" or "qualia" aspect of the mind.
Consciousness is often divided into two parts: phenomenal
consciou sness, which refers to our experiences, emotions, and
feelings, and access consciousness, which refers to the mental
processes that underlie our ability to reflect, reason, and remember.
Awareness, on the other hand, is a more specific term that refers to
the ability to directly know and perceive, to feel, or to be cognizant of
events. It often signifies a higher level of consciousness, where one is
not just sentient but also self -aware.

While it is correct that DNA doesn't do anything without being

shape the characteristics of an organism. This is why identical  twins,
despite having the same DNA, can still have differences.
DNA also contains instructions for more than just the production of
proteins. It controls when and where those proteins are made, and in
what quantities, which is crucial for the development and functioning

chapter: Max Planck's first paper on quantum theory reflected the
text:
quantized effect of the subatomic level by introducing the idea that
light energy is not continuous, but discrete and indivisible. He
proposed that light consists of packets of energy called ‘quanta ’ or
‘photons’, and that the energy of each photon is proportional to its
frequency. This means that light can only have certain discrete values
of energy, and not any arbitrary value. This concept of quantization
was later extended to other physical quant ities, such as the angular
Robert De Filippis

momentum and the energy of electrons in atoms. Quantum
mechanics is the branch of physics that deals with the behavior of
matter and light on the atomic and subatomic scale, and it is based on
the principle of quantization. One of the consequences of quant um
mechanics is that subatomic particles, such as electrons, protons,
neutrons, quarks and gluons, have both particle -like and wave -like
properties, known as ‘wave -particle duality’. Another consequence is
that there are limits to how precisely one can mea sure the position
and momentum of a particle at the same time, known as ‘the
uncertainty principle.’ These phenomena are very different from the
classical physics that applies to macroscopic objects, and they reveal
the fundamental nature of reality at the  smallest scales.

chapter: zero -point energy , vibrational energy that molecules retain even at
text:
the absolute zero of temperature. Temperature in physics has been
found to be a measure of the intensity of random molecular motion,
and it might be expected that, as temperature is reduced to absolute
zero, all motion ceases and molecules come to rest. In fact, however,
the motion corresponding to zero -point energy never vanishes. Zero -
point energy results from principles of quantum theory, the physics of
subatomic phenomena. Should the molecules ever come  completely
to rest, their component atoms would be precisely located and would
simultaneously have precisely specified velocities, namely, of value
zero. But it is an axiom of quantum theory that no object can ever have
precise values of position and velo city simultaneously ( see uncertainty
principle); thus, molecules can never come completely to rest.

PREFACE
This is the third book in a journey —one that began
with a growing discomfort at the limits of materialist
thinking.
In Signals in the Noise , (DeFilippis, Signals in
the Noise: Encountering the Limits of Materialist
Science, 2024)  I explored the rising disconnect
between how we live and what we actually know. I
argued that our cultural and cognitive systems are
flooded with distractions, leaving us deaf to the
deeper signals —intuition, emotion, instinct —that try
to guide us from wi thin.
In The Unified Mind , (DeFilippis, The Unified
Mind: Staying Sane in a Fractured Nation, 2025)  I
took that inquiry a step further. I suggested that our
split between reason and faith, logic and intuition,
has left us mentally fragmented and spiritually
undernourished.

from choosing one faculty over another, but fro m
integrating our full range of mental capabilities —
building a mind that can reason and reflect, calculate
and connect.
Yet even then, a deeper question remained:
What is this mind we’re trying to unify? Where does
it begin? Is it in the brain —or does it start earlier,
deeper, in the body itself?
That question led me here, to The Embodied
Mind .
This book is the result of my ongoing attempt to
understand consciousness —not as a philosophical
abstraction, but as a practical, lived reality. It moves

Even more striking, a 2023 paper by Jack

misunderstanding of consciousness is putting our
species at risk. We cannot afford to sleepwalk
through reality any longer. We must learn to use our
minds —fully, wisely, and with awareness —before
ignorance, dist raction, and unconscious habit
destroy what remains of our shared humanity.
This book , like all my others,  offers no final
answers. But it does offer a path —a way to listen
more deeply, perceive more clearly, and live more
consciously.
If Signals in the Noise was a call to pay attention,
and The Unified Mind was a call to integration, then
The Embodied Mind is a call to return —return to the
body, to presence, to the felt knowing that existed
long before we learned to explain ourselves.
And perhaps, it’s also a call to remember that our
bodies have always known what our brains are still
trying to figure out.

chapter: INTRODUCT ION
text:
For as long as we’ve studied consciousness, we’ve
asked the same kind of questions: What is it? Where
does it come from? Is it physical or immaterial?
These are ontological questions —questions about
what consciousness is. And while they’ve generated
endless theories, elegant models, and countless
academic debates, they’ve done very little to help us
actually live better lives.
We still suffer. We still react. We still don’t
understand why we know what we know —or why
that knowing sometimes comes as a gut feeling, a
flash of intuition, or a bodily reaction long before a
single thought forms in the brain.
Maybe that’s because we’ve been looking in the
wrong direction.
In this book, I propose a shift —from ontology to
epistemology. That is, instead of asking what
consciousness is, let’s ask how it works.
What if consciousness isn’t a static property of the
brain, but a dynamic process unfolding throughout
the body?

Malcolm Gladwell, in his book Blink , introduced

decisions are the ones we make in the blink of an eye.
He called it thin-slicing —our ability to make
surprisingly accurate judgments based on a thin slice
of experience or information.
The classic example is an art expert who, at first
glance, instinctively knows a sculpture is a fake —
even though they can’t immediately explain why. Or
the emergency room doctor who knows something is
wrong before the test results come in. In both cases,
the decision is fast, intuitive, and often more
accurate than one reached through long
deliberation.

snap judgments. But Gladwell isn’t saying all
intuition is trustworthy —far from it. What he’s
arguing is that when our unconscious mind has been
trained by experience, it becomes a finely tuned
instrument.

"Time is a measure of change, not a substance that
flows."
— Aristotle (Physics IV), paraphrased
In the early 21st century, a profound shift
emerged in theoretical physics: the idea that
spacetime itself is not fundamental. Rather than a
fixed stage upon which the universe plays out, space
and time are being reimagined as emergent
phenomena arising fr om deeper, more primary
processes —particularly quantum temporal
correlations.
In their 2025 paper, "Geometry from Quantum
Temporal Correlations," physicists James Fullwood
and Vlatko Vedral offered a stunning proposal: that
the geometry of three -dimensional space can emerge
from the sequential measurements of a single qubit
using Pa uli spin observables —σₓ, σᵧ, σ_z. These
measurements don ’t rely on any pre -existing spatial
structure, nor even on the qubit ’s initial state.
Instead, structure appears through the correlation
between events in time.
